Default status is 501 Not Implemented

docblock.description: Headers that need to be sent
Is this response handled via fcgi?
Sets if the response should be handled like fcgi
Is this response handled via HTTP?
Sets if the response should be handled like HTTP
Adds a response header to be sent
docblock.long-description:
Arguments 2-N are imploded with '; ' to allow easier setting of headers like:

$response->addHeader('Content-Disposition', 'attachment', 'filename=fname.ext');

Which is output as: Content-Disposition: attachment; filename=fname.ext

docblock.description: Formats the Status header for FGCI or HTTP
Formats a header based off an array item
Creates and sends any needed headers

tag.name: param
tag.description: the HTTP header data For the header <code>Authorization: Basic QWxhZGRpbjpvcGVuIHNlc2FtZQ==</code> Pass <code>Basic QWxhZGRpbjpvcGVuIHNlc2FtZQ==</code>

docblock.description: HTTP Request header containing a list of all content-codings that are acceptable similar to Accept header
docblock.long-description: An example header would be Accept-Encoding: compress, gzip Accept-Encoding: Accept-Encoding: * Accept-Encoding: compress;q=0.5, gzip;q=1.0 Accept-Encoding: gzip;q=1.0, identity; q=0.5, *;q=0

docblock.description: Sorted list of content-codings the client will accept

tag.name: param
tag.description: the value of the Accept-Encoding header after the colon

docblock.description: Gets all content-codings that this user agent accepts
Gets the preferred content-codings of the user-agent. Usually the first item listed in the header unless all content-codings are weighted
Does the User-Agent accept this content-codings?
docblock.long-description: The "identity" content-coding is always acceptable, unless specifically refused because the Accept-Encoding field includes "identity;q=0", or because the field includes "*;q=0" and does not explicitly include the "identity" content-coding. If the Accept-Encoding field-value is empty, then only the "identity" encoding is acceptable.

docblock.description: HTTP Request header containing a list of all Character Sets that are acceptable similar to Accept header
docblock.long-description:
An example header would be Accept-Charset: iso-8859-5, unicode-1-1;q=0.8

The special value "", if present in the Accept-Charset field, matches every character set (including ISO-8859-1) which is not mentioned elsewhere in the Accept-Charset field. If no "" is present in an Accept-Charset field, then all character sets not explicitly mentioned get a quality value of 0, except for ISO-8859-1, which gets a quality value of 1 if not explicitly mentioned.

If no Accept-Charset header is present, the default is that any character set is acceptable. If an Accept-Charset header is present, and if the server cannot send a response which is acceptable according to the Accept-Charset header, then the server SHOULD send an error response with the 406 (not acceptable) status code, though the sending of an unacceptable response is also allowed.

docblock.description: Sorted list of charsets the client will accept

tag.name: param
tag.description: the value of the Accept-Charset header after the colon

docblock.description: Gets all charsets that this user agent accepts
Gets the preferred charset of the user-agent. Usually the first item listed in the header unless all charsets are weighted
Does the User-Agent accept this charset?
docblock.long-description: If the agent has a wildcard (*) or no Accept-Charset header this will return true per the RFC

docblock.description: HTTP Request header containing a list of all languages the user-agent accepts
docblock.long-description:
The Accept-Language request-header field is similar to Accept, but restricts the set of natural languages that are preferred as a response to the request.

An example header would be Accept-Language: da, en-gb;q=0.8, en;q=0.7 Which means: "I prefer Danish, but will accept British English and other types of English." A language-range matches a language-tag if it exactly equals the tag, or if it exactly equals a prefix of the tag such that the first tag character following the prefix is "-". The special range "*", if present in the Accept-Language field, matches every tag not matched by any other range present in the Accept-Language field.

docblock.description: Sorted list of languages the client will accept

tag.name: param
tag.description: the value of the Accept-Language header after the colon

docblock.description: Gets all languages that this user agent accepts
Gets the preferred langauges of the user-agent. Usually the first item listed in the header unless all languages are weighted
Does the User-Agent accept this language?

docblock.description: HTTP Request header containing a list of all Content-Types that are acceptable
docblock.long-description: An example header would be Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,* /*;q=0.8,application/json;q=0.0

docblock.description: Sorted list of mime-types the client will accept

docblock.long-description: Code inspired by Wez Furlong

tag.name: param
tag.description: the value of the Accept header after the colon

docblock.description: Gets all mime types that this user agent accepts
Gets the preferred mime type of the user-agent. Usually the first item listed in the header unless all mimes are weighted
Does the User-Agent accept this mime type?
docblock.long-description: If the agent has a wildcard in accept * /* this will return true
